banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: Why is 'x' the unknown?

recommendations.blurb: Still searching for "x"? Read discussions and debates around the origin of the unknown variable, and find out more about Islamic mathematical advancements.

recItems.blurb: Interested viewers can read alternative opinions and discussion here.
recItems.headline: Why are x and y such common variables in today's equations?
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.headline: Explanation: Why x, y, z are always variables
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: A good book for interested viewers.
recItems.headline: A History of Mathematical Notations
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.headline: The Algebra of Mohammed Ben Musa
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: For anyone interested in the larger topic of the Islamic scientific and intellectual tradition and its influence, I recommend the works of Seyyed Hossein Nasr.
recItems.headline: Science and Civilization in Islam
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.headline: Islamic Philosophy from Its Origin to the Present
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

nodes.whatOthersSay: His useful and whimsical presentation on how to tie shoes correctly was an easy way to return home from Monterey a better and wiser person.
nodes.whoTheyAre: Terry Moore is the director of the Radius Foundation, a forum for exploring and gaining insight from different worldviews.
nodes.whyListen:
Terry Moore directs the Radius Foundation in New York, which, as its website says, "seeks new ways of exploring and understanding dissimilar conceptual systems or paradigms -- scientific, religious, philosophical, and aesthetic -- with the aim to find a world view of more complete insight and innovation. The Radius Foundation is a forum for different views."

The foundation has published several works that examine the intersection of religion and metaphysics with science and social action.

videoData.description: Why is 'x' the symbol for an unknown? In this short and funny talk, Terry Moore gives the surprising answer.
videoData.socialDescription: Why is 'x' the symbol for an unknown? In this short and funny talk, Terry Moore gives the surprising answer.

cues.text: I have the answer to a question that we've all asked.
Why is it that the letter X
Now I know we learned that in math class,
but now it's everywhere in the culture --
I decided that I would learn Arabic,
which turns out to be a supremely logical language.
To write a word or a phrase
because every part is extremely precise
and carries a lot of information.
so much of what we've come to think of
as Western science and mathematics and engineering
was really worked out in the first few centuries of the Common Era
by the Persians and the Arabs and the Turks.
This includes the little system in Arabic
Al-jebr finally came into English as algebra.
The Arabic texts containing this mathematical wisdom
finally made their way to Europe --
is there are some sounds in Arabic
that just don't make it through a European voice box
by the characters that are available in European languages.
and it makes the sound we think of as SH -- "sh."
It's also the very first letter
just like the the English word "something" --
And this is a word that appears throughout early mathematics,
such as this 10th-century derivation of roots.
The problem for the Medieval Spanish scholars
who were tasked with translating this material
is that the letter sheen and the word shayun
because Spanish doesn't have that SH,
they created a rule in which
they borrowed the CK sound, "ck" sound,
in the form of the letter Kai.
Later when this material was translated
they simply replaced the Greek Kai
once this material was in Latin,
it formed the basis for mathematics textbooks
But now we have the answer to our question.
Why is it that X is the unknown?
because you can't say "sh" in Spanish.
And I thought that was worth sharing.
